title: Recruitment Consultant - Career Insights (Careers in Recruitment & HR)
author: Career Insights

key_facts: Hannah worked as a recruitment consultant in Australia before moving back to the UK.
She transitioned from agency recruitment to internal recruitment at G4S for front-of-house and security staff.
At G4S, she recruited for global accounts including Google, Facebook, and Snapchat.
She later returned to agency recruitment in London focusing on marketing and communications roles.
Her current role involves recruiting for FMCG companies and retail media agencies.
She previously worked as a brand manager in an FMCG company and in an HR internship during university.
She did not require formal qualifications to enter recruitment, emphasizing personality over credentials.
She recruits for roles across multiple industries, including finance and HR, even if not her specialty.
She splits her day between morning client calls and afternoon candidate outreach.
She uses LinkedIn, market research, and Google Alerts to stay informed about industry trends.
She values writing job ads with no typos, believing poor grammar discourages applicants.
She conducts research on market shifts, mergers, and legislative changes affecting hiring.
She attends seminars and subscribes to daily bulletins to stay updated on industry news.
She finds personal satisfaction when candidates she placed receive promotions.
She describes recruitment as having long hours and emotionally volatile days.
key_opinions: Recruitment is more than filling vacancies—it's about strategic talent development.
Confidence and the ability to 'fake it till you make it' are essential for success.
A thick skin is necessary due to frequent rejection and difficult interactions.
The best recruiters are those who deeply understand their market and can advise clients confidently.
Having a background in business or HR helps in understanding organizational needs.
English language skills are crucial for writing professional job advertisements.
Meeting new people every day makes recruitment a fun and social career path.
Long hours are a major downside but manageable with the right mindset.
Internal roles offer better work-life balance compared to agency work.
Recruitment is ideal for confident, outgoing individuals who enjoy building relationships.
The emotional reward of seeing candidates succeed outweighs the challenges.
Clients often expect recruiters to know everything about roles they’re recruiting for.
Personal interest or prior experience in an industry increases job fit and satisfaction.
Success in recruitment comes from persistence and continuous learning.
The role requires constant networking and relationship-building with clients and candidates.
key_datapoints: Hannah moved from Australia to the UK after her Tier visa expired.
She worked at G4S for approximately nine to ten months in internal recruitment.
She has been in her current agency role in London for an unspecified duration.
She spends roughly half her day on client communication and half on candidate engagement.
She checks market updates during commutes—on trains into and out of work.
She uses Google Alerts to monitor industry changes and receives them via email.
She attends seminars and talks regularly to stay informed about recruitment trends.
She writes job ads based on detailed briefs including qualifications and responsibilities.
She recruits for roles across multiple sectors, including marketing, communications, finance, and HR.
She has placed candidates who later received promotions, which she finds personally rewarding.
She estimates that some days involve no responses or lost opportunities to competitors.
She reports that perfect candidates sometimes appear unexpectedly, leading to successful placements.
She works from around 8:30 AM, indicating early office arrival times.
She views the role as emotionally intense, with extreme highs and lows in performance.
She believes that 18 months is a typical timeframe for a candidate to achieve promotion after placement.
